Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Preventive Factors in Free Flap Surgery for Head and Neck Reconstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable due to the retrospective nature of the study.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a tertiary referral center from 2019 to 2022, the study included 110 patients who underwent free flap reconstructions. Participants were selected based on eligibility criteria, excluding those with missing outcome data.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to identify factors preventing complications in free flap surgery for head and neck reconstruction to support clinical decision-making.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was complication-free survival (CFS) at 30 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not applicable due to the retrospective nature of the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 30-day CFS was 63%. Multivariable analysis identified female gender (HR: 9.4, CI: 2.6–33.5), alcohol abuse (HR: 3.5, CI: 1.4–8.4), and obesity (HR: 2.1, CI: 0.9–5.1) as significant risk factors.
